description: On April 1, 2020, Minister Divjak announced that Matura exam in Croatian language would not be taken on May 16, 2020. On 15 April, she confirmed that Matura will most likely be held in June. On June 8, 2020, the National Center for External Evaluation of Education (NCVVO) stated the Matura exam would take place from June 8 to July 3, separated into blocks June 8 to 24 and June 25 to July 3.

description: On March 3, 2020, Croatia announced the Border Sanitary Inspector or the Sanitary Inspector of the Regional or Central Office of the State Inspectorate will have trucking companies complete questionnaires to confirm truckers are not ill and have not been in contact with someone infected with COVID-19. They will then be under health surveillance as long as the area the driver goes to or from is affected by COVID-19 and they have discussed their travels and health with an epidemiologist. Proof of this discussion with the epidemiologist is required upon returning to Croatia from an affected country to prove to the border patrol officer that the truck driver was already under surveillance.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On March 19, 2020, Croatia banned transit through all its border crossings for 30 days, excluding Croatian citizens and foreign nationals returning home, law enforcement, cross-border workers, freight carriers, healthcare professionals, diplomats, civil protection services and teams, staff of international organizations and international military personnel, and passengers in transit. Also excluded are citizens EU and Schengen zone residents as well as those with long-term residence and persons entitled to residence or national long-term visas. These individuals are allowed to return to their home countries.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On March 30, 2020, the Croatian Police Directorate has called upon all foreigners on short stay in Croatia who are not able to leave Croatia to send their information to the police in order to be registered. This will help prevent problems at border crossings when leaving the Republic of Croatia.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_text: registration of foreigners who are unable to leave Croatia
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On March 31, 2020, the Republic of Croatia temporarily closed six permanent border crossings (Umag, Poreč, Rovinj, Mali Lošinj, Korčula and Ubli) and postponed the opening of eleven seasonal crossings (Umag-ACI Marina, Novigrad, Sali, Božava, Primošten, Komiža, Hvar, Vis, Stari Grad on the island of Hvar, Vela Luka and Cavtat) for international passenger traffic in maritime transport. On June 10, 2020, Croatia stated the reopening of maritime border crossing points and lifted the temporary postponement of seasonal border crossings.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On April 2, 2020, the Croatian Police Directorate announced that Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina have agreed to temporarily close 20 of their mutual border crossings. The traffic is suspended at the following border crossings: Svilaj, Gejkovac, Pasin Potok, Bogovolja, Kordunski Ljeskovac, Licka Kaldrma, Bili Brig, Arzano Pazar, Dvorine, Cera, Jovica Most, Sebisina, Slivno, Podprolog, Unka, Vukov Klanac, Imotica, Slano, Hrvatska Dubica and Gabela Polje.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: On March 19, 2020, Croatia banned transit through all its border crossings for 30 days, excluding Croatian citizens and foreign nationals returning home, law enforcement, cross-border workers, freight carriers, healthcare professionals, diplomats, civil protection services and teams, staff of international organizations and international military personnel, and passengers in transit. Also excluded are citizens EU and Schengen zone residents as well as those with long-term residence and persons entitled to residence or national long-term visas. description:
As of April 20, 2020, Croatia stated Vehicles in transit through Croatia will use the following border crossing points:
 Croatia – Slovenia border: Bregana and Macelj
 Croatia – Hungary border: Goričan and Duboševica
 Croatia – Bosnia and Herzegovina border: Nova Sela, Stara Gradiška and Slavonski Šamac
 Croatia – Serbia border: Bajakovo

description: Starting May 11, 2020, Croatia stated people entering Croatia would no longer be required to self-isolate but would need to follow strict guidelines. They will be required to keep their contacts with other people to the minimum, spend as little time as possible outdoors and maintain hygiene. They are also advised to wear face masks and take their body temperature regularly. If they become symptomatic, Croatian nationals need to report to their GP while foreign nationals should contact the epidemiological service.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On Mar 31 the Croatian Science Foundation with financing from the Ministry of Science and Education has invited scientists to apply for 14 million kuna in grants for research related to the coronavirus. The researchers have 18 months to complete their projects.

description: On March 3, 2020, Croatia stated truck drivers must adhere to basic hygiene procedures. When loading or waiting for loading in facilities within the COVID-19 affected regions, they must use gloves, masks, and protective equipment. They must have hand sanitizer with them in situations where hands cannot be regularly washed. Alcohol disinfectant or similar is acceptable.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: On March 3, 2020, Croatia stated if a driver transporting passengers with a passenger a suspected to have COVID-19, but the driver's compartment is separate from the rest of the vehicle, it is not necessary to wear a mask. One must maintain hand hygiene by washing more frequently or using 70% disinfecting gel, while also maintaining a distance of a 1 meter in social contact.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)

description: On March 3, 2020, Croatia stated if a driver who has no direct contact with a passenger suspected of COVID-19, but without a barrier between the driver compartment and the rest of the vehicle, must adhere to one meter of distance. Particular importance is placed on hand hygiene and disinfecting gels of at least 70% alcohol.

description: On May 4th, both hair and beauty salons will be opening up with hygiene regulations including: mandatory posting of information on hygiene, social distancing (1.5 meters) between clients and staff (Plexiglass barrier recommended for regular cleaning and disinfection), disinfectants (must be available in waiting rooms/entrance area, payment desk, and work area). It is recommended that towels and gowns are replaced by disposable towels and gowns and that both staff and clients wear gloves and face masks.

description: On Apr 1  2020 , the Croatian coronavirus crisis team declared that as of April 6 leaving one's place of residence will be possible only with an e-pass. The e-passes will be issued for a period of one to fourteen days, depending on the reason.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On Apr 1 the Croatian coronavirus crisis team declared that as of April 6 moving between different administrative units of the country, will be possible only with an e-pass. The e-passes will be issued for a period of one to fourteen days, depending on the reason.

On April 19, National Civil Protection Headquarters declared that from April 20 e-passes for movement between the area of the City of Zagreb and Zagreb County have been abolished. Passes for Vukovar-Srijem County, Osijek-Baranja County, Varaždin County, Karlovac County, Brod-Posavina County, Požega County, Slavonia County and Split-Dalmatia County are also being abolished, with the exception of the islands, while the Lika-Senj County Civil Protection Headquarters will decide on Monday. UPDATE: The e-passes were cancelled for the big part of the territory on April 19, and therefore I am ending this policy.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On May 9th, 2020, the Croatian National Civil Protection Headquarters declared that residents of Brač cannot leave the island without e-passes, for a period of 14 days.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On Dec 18 the Croatian Civil Protection Headquarters declared that as of December 23 moving between different administrative units of the country, will be possible only with an e-pass. This policy lasted until December 29, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On March 22, 2020, the Croatian Ministry of Interior declared: people will be banned from leaving their place of residence as of Mar 23, 2020. 

Exempt from the measure are: those are important for transport that is necessary for supply, daily migrations, the employed in important services for healthcare and veterinary protection, delivery of medicines, sanitary materials, maintaining utilities, water supply and sewage, provision of natural gas and electricity, informing the public, journalists, citizens that require urgent medical assistance, vital family reasons, travelling to work and from work if doing a job is absolutely necessary and can’t be done from home, as well as urgent operative services that are taking part in preventing spread of the disease.

Passes will be required and signed by appropriate entities.
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 26, 2020, the Croatian Ministry of Interior stated that if truck drivers are in Croatia less than 24 hours, they must remain in their trucks during their free time. If they notice any kind of symptoms they must contact their doctors.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable)

description:
On March 22, 2020, the Croatian Ministry of Interior declared: people will be banned from leaving their place of residence as of Mar 23, 2020. 

Exempt from the measure are: those are important for transport that is necessary for supply, daily migrations, the employed in important services for healthcare and veterinary protection, delivery of medicines, sanitary materials, maintaining utilities, water supply and sewage, provision of natural gas and electricity, informing the public, journalists, citizens that require urgent medical assistance, vital family reasons, travelling to work and from work if doing a job is absolutely necessary and can’t be done from home, as well as urgent operative services that are taking part in preventing spread of the disease.

Passes will be required and signed by appropriate entities. UPDATE: On April 18, 2020, the Croatian Interior Minister Davor Bozinovic stated the lockdown will be extended until May 4, 2020, but the government will look at whether it was possible to gradually ease restrictions on movement.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 22, 2020, the Croatian Ministry of Interior declared: people will be banned from leaving their place of residence as of Mar 23, 2020. On April 18, 2020, the Croatian Interior Minister Davor Bozinovic stated the lockdown will be extended until May 4, 2020, but the government will look at whether it was possible to gradually ease restrictions on movement. UPDATE: On April 27, 2020, Croatia started a staged easing of the mandatory lockdown.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On March 22, 2020, the Croatian Ministry of Interior declared: people will be banned from leaving their place of residence as of Mar 23, 2020. On April 18, 2020, the Croatian Interior Minister Davor Bozinovic stated the lockdown will be extended until May 4, 2020. On April 27, 2020, Croatia started a staged easing of the mandatory lockdown. UPDATE: On May 11, 2020, Croatia fully repealed the lockdown.

a new decision on regulation of movement between counties which opened the possibility for counties, i.e. county civil protection headquarters, to propose the abolition of the ban on leaving the county of residence.

description: On April 1, 2020, the Croatian Prime Minister announced Croatia would be increasing the net minimum wage to HRK 4,000 (€725) and partly or fully exempting some businesses from taxes for April, May, and July.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_text: This is aid to businesses and individuals as a result of COVID-19

description: On January 23, at the initiative of the Ministry of Health, the Croatian Institute of Public Health has published a multilingual leaflet and a notification on coronavirus for travellers to China (in Croatian, English and Chinese).

26 February 2020 The daily sessions of the Civil Protection Headquarters of the Republic of Croatia were introduced at 9 am and 4 pm, after which press releases were issued and published on the website Civil Protection Directorate.
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 18, the Croatian government established a COVID-19 call centers where epidemiologists and other professionals can answer citizens questions every day from 8am to 4pm.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 14, the Croatian Ministry of Health introduced Andrija - the first digital coronavirus assistant in Croatia. The app helps people recognize symptoms of coronavirus infection (self-assessment of their own health status), connects people to competent institutions, allows people to report relevant information from their household, and helps nursing home employees understand health protocols.
type_sub_cat: Both Disseminating and Gathering information related to COVID-19
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 27, the  The Croatian Institute of Public Health and the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Croatia established an Open Data Portal which collects data regarding COVID-19 and ensures transparency with real-time data that citizens can access at any time.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On February 21, 2020 the Croatian Institute of Public Health initiated the quarantine of persons who were identified or suspected to have been in direct contact with patients with COVID-19 while on board ships. The designated quarantine unit is at the Infectious Diseases Clinic “Dr Fran Mihaljevic” in Zagreb.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On February 24, 2020, the Crisis Headquarters of the Ministry of Health stated that for all persons who have been in close contact with a patient who has COVID-19, self-isolation is foreseen in their own home with daily contact with the epidemiologist or organized quarantine if there are no conditions for self-isolation.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On February 24, 2020. the Croatian Crisis Headquarters of the Ministry of Health presented additional measures that Croatia will take against the spread of coronavirus including: 
All travelers coming from the affected areas are foreseen to be placed in self-isolation with health surveillance and are obliged to report daily to the epidemiologist. The affected areas include China, the Republic of Korea (South Korea) and the provinces of Lombardy and Veneto in Italy. This policy ended on March 12, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: On March 9, 2020, Croatia stated truck drivers who drive to coronavirus affected areas must stay in self-isolation upon arrival in Croatia until they leave for the next transport. Upon their return, they are obliged to undergo self-isolation.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable)

description: On March 12, 2020, Croatia announced that Drivers in cross-border traffic who enter the Republic of Croatia, except for drivers in transit, and come from areas affected by coronavirus, based on the decision of the sanitary inspection will be sent to self-isolation for 14 days.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 16, 2020, Croatia announced that anyone disobeying the order to self-isolate or other measures imposed over the coronavirus outbreak faces a fine of HRK 8,000 (€1,060), while repeat offenders face a fine of up to HRK 120,000 (€16,000).
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 9, 2020, Croatia stated truck drivers who drive to coronavirus affected areas must stay in self-isolation upon arrival in Croatia until they leave for the next transport. Upon their return, they are obliged to undergo self-isolation. UPDATE: On March 20, 2020, the Croatian Ministry of Health stated truck drivers will not leave their cabin for unloading goods. After unloading, drivers will quarantine in their homes or isolation organizes by their company. If organized by their company, they may break quarantine to return to work. They may not break quarantine if they are in their own homes or another private location.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable)

date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On March 9, 2020, Croatia stated truck drivers who drive to coronavirus affected areas must stay in self-isolation upon arrival in Croatia until they leave for the next transport. Upon their return, they are obliged to undergo self-isolation. On March 20, 2020, Croatia stated after unloading, drivers will quarantine in their homes or isolation organizes by their company. UPDATE: On March 26, 2020, Croatia announced quarantines organized by the employer are no longer required.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
On April 17, Croatian Parliament, pursuant to Article 89 of the Constitution of the Republic of Croatia, enacted decision on the promulgation of the law on amendments to the law on protection of the population from infectious diseases. 

With new amendments, for the people who are suspected of suffering from COVID-19 disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus or healthy persons who have been in contact with persons suffering from the disease, or come from the area of the affected COVID-19 disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, health professionals may determine the isolation in their own home, or in another suitable space - a self-isolation, if appropriate conditions are met (Art. 8). 

Furthermore, for each violation of the provisions of this Act, the sanitary inspector of the State Inspectorate may, on the spot, charge a fine in the amount of HRK 5,000.00 (660 euros). (Art. 17).
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On Mar 26 the Croatian Ministry of Interior declared to liberalize the procedure related to Croatian and foreign citizens that drive for Croatian employers in international transport. Following loading or unloading they can be in self-isolation at their homes and no longer have to go into quarantine. If they notice any kind of symptoms they must contact their doctors. UPDATE: As of May 7, 2020, Croatia stated the requirement for international goods drivers to quarantine upon arrival does not apply anymore.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Effective May 11, 2020, Croatia announced people entering Croatia are no longer required to self-isolate, but must keep contacts with other people to a minimum, spend as little time as possible outdoors, and maintain hygiene. They are advised to wear face masks and take their body temperature regularly. If symptoms arise, Croatian nationals must report to their GP while foreign nationals should contact the epidemiological service.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On February 21,2020, the Croatian Institute of Public Health initiated the quarantine of persons who were identified or suspected to have been in direct contact with patients with COVID-19 while on board ships. The designated quarantine unit is at the Infectious Diseases Clinic “Dr Fran Mihaljevic” in Zagreb. UPDATE: Effective May 11, 2020, Croatia stated people entering the country are no longer required to self-isolate but would still need to follow strict guidelines.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On March 12, 2020, Croatia announced that Drivers in cross-border traffic who enter the Republic of Croatia, except for drivers in transit, and come from areas affected by coronavirus, based on the decision of the sanitary inspection will be sent to self-isolation for 14 days. UPDATE: Effective May 11, 2020, Croatia stated people entering the country are no longer required to self-isolate but would still need to follow strict guidelines.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On June 25, 2020, Croatian Civil Protection Headquarters introduced mandatory self-isolation for people entering Croatia from Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, North Macedonia and Serbia. There are exceptions for those who, due to the nature of their work and living circumstances, will not have to isolate themselves, and among them are cross-border workers and those transiting through these four countries and through Croatia. Additionally, those crossing for a funeral, medical care, or transport will not be subjected to this rule.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: Effective May 11, 2020, Croatia announced people entering Croatia are no longer required to self-isolate, but must keep contacts with other people to a minimum, spend as little time as possible outdoors, and maintain hygiene. They are advised to wear face masks and take their body temperature regularly. If symptoms arise, Croatian nationals must report to their GP while foreign nationals should contact the epidemiological service. UPDATE: On June 25, 2020, Croatia introduced a mandatory self-isolation for individuals entering Croatia from Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, North Macedonia and Serbia with limited exceptions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Mar 14 Istria County his shuttering all hospitality businesses for the next month in a move to try and curb the spread of the coronavirus. All cafes and restaurants will be closed until April 14. Food delivery services and soup kitchens are exempt but are under strict cautionary measures, said Damir Kozlovac, the head of county civil defense services.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is closed/locked down

description: Effective March 22, 2020, the Croatian national civil protection authority decided to suspend all public transportation services, including transport by tram, for the next 30 days. This measure includes:  public passenger transport by road within the country (except for taxi services), international public passenger transport by road, passenger transport by rail, tram and other city public transportation, as well as all other types of public transportation (such as funicular railway). This policy ended on May 11, 2020, when the government allowed intercity road, rail transport, and other forms of public transportation to resume in accordance with the regulations announced April 27, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On March 19, 2020, Croatia is putting a ban on the gathering of more than 5 people in one place for 30 days. This policy was extended until May 11, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On March 19, Croatian government cancelled religious services (all public events, gatherings, and meetings of more than 5 persons in one place). The policy ended on May 2, allowing religious services to resume. UPDATE: Originally, on March 19, religious services were cancelled. However, the policy ended on May 2, since religious services were able to resume.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)

description:
9 March 2020 the Croatian National headquarters for coronavirus introduced new measures to prevent spreading of virus: It is recommended to postpone all public events with more than 1000 people. If organizers however decide to organize such events, they must ensure high hygienic standards. On Mar 12 the Croatian government recommended postponement or limitation of gatherings with more than 100 people, as well as sports events without spectators. Effective March 19, all sports competitions will be closed. 
 UPDATE: Originally, in Croatia, sports competitions that included more than 100 people were recommended to be suspended. However, effective March 19, all sports competitions will be closed.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 19, 2020, Croatia prohibited public gatherings and cancelled sporting events. UPDATE: Croatia originally recommended sporting events be held without spectators, but this is now mandatory as sporting events are cancelled.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On March 9, 2020, Croatia recommended postponing all public events with more than 1000 people. On March 12, 2020, Croatia recommended the postponement or limitation of gatherings of more than 100 people. 
 UPDATE: On March 19, 2020, Croatia stated public gatherings are now prohibited for 30 days.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 21, the government of Croatia announced that only immediate family and religious community representatives may attend funerals.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 21, the government of Croatia announced that only immediate family and religious community representatives may attend funerals. This measured was extended until May 4 with the following precautionary measures: no music, flowers or candles, and obituaries may not contain information on the time and place of the funeral UPDATE: The original restriction (March 21) of funerals being limited to immediate family members and religious representatives was extended to May 4.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 19, 2020, Croatia is putting a ban on the gathering of more than 5 people in one place for 30 days. UPDATE: Beginning May 11, 2020, Croatia stated public gatherings of up to 10 people were allowed outdoors.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On March 3 the Croatian Institute of Public Health has issued recommendations for the preservation of health of persons over 60 years of age and those suffering from chronic diseases who should avoid visits and entry into crowded public areas and routine check-ups and visits to general practitioners and hospitals should be skipped unless there is a need for urgent health care services.
On March 16, the Ministry of Health in Croatia announced their recommendation for people suffering respiratory infection symptoms to wear a mask.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People with certain health conditions (please note which health conditions in the text entry)

description: On Mar 17 the Croatian national civil defense headquarters has once again called to limit the movement of the elderly so that they do not leave their residences unless absolutely necessary. UPDATE: Elderly people should not only avoid mass gatherings but limit going outdoors in general.
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: In Croatia on March 19, the government implemented a strict measurement of social distancing to avoid close personal contact at a distance of at least two (2) meters indoors and one (1) meter outdoors for 30 days.

On Mar 21 the Croatia national civil protection authority decided to suspend all public transportation services, including transport by rail, bus and tram, for the next 30 days, and the decision goes into force on Sunday, March 22.
All railway and bus stations will be closed. Travel to islands will be possible only for people who live on islands.
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on ridership of subways and trams
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 27, 2020, Croatia stated close contact businesses will remain closed. On May 4, 2020, Croatia allowed close contact businesses such as hairdressers, beauticians, barbers, pedicure, etc to reopen.

description: On May 11, 2020, Preschools and classes from grades 1 to 4 and classes with children with disabilities will reopen. Additionally, students would be allowed to attend laboratory, art, and clinical practical classes in small groups.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: On May 14, the Croatian Institute of Public Health issued recommendations of social distancing for visitors at  beaches as well as freshwater and sea swimming areas. These recommendations include  a maximum number of 15 people per one hundred square meters on the beaches and maintaining 1.5 m physical distance between individuals in the water.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 24, the Croatian Institute of Public Health issued a recommendation for drivers of public transportation (buses and trams) to wear masks. This policy was updated on June 25 which required both drivers and passengers in public transportation to wear masks.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Beginning June 25, 2020, Croatia stated masks are mandatory on public transport in Croatia for both drivers and passengers. A passenger who does not have a medical or face mask will not be allowed to enter the transport.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
